chapter.htmlHeader: Scenario: Known cause of cough
chapter.summary: Covers the palliative cancer care management of a person with cough of known cause, including infection.
chapter.htmlStringContent: From age 16 years onwards.

chapters.fullItemName: Have I got the right topic?

subChapters.fullItemName: Prevalence of cough in palliative care
Causes of cough in palliative care
All people with cough in palliative care
subChapters.htmlHeader: What management should be considered for all people with cough in palliative care?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Treat the underlying cause of the cough if possible and appropriate. The decision to treat the underlying cause of the cough will depend on:
    • The wishes of the person.
    • The inconvenience and risks of the investigations of the cause.
    • The likely benefit of treatments.
    • The person's life expectancy.
  • Review medication and consider whether it is appropriate to switch to an alternative or to discontinue the medication which might be exacerbating cough (for example an angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitor).
  • Consider the presence of co-existing causes of a chronic cough (for example asthma, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, gastro-oesophageal reflux disease, and heart failure). For further information on management of these conditions see the CKS topics on:
    • Asthma
    • Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease
    • Dyspepsia - proven GORD
    • Heart failure - chronic
  • Aim to relieve symptoms (for example nurse the person in the position that causes least discomfort, avoid smoke or fumes, consider humidifying air).
    • Treatment of infection with antibiotics, drainage of effusions, radiotherapy to tumour masses or lymphadenopathy, or stenting of tracheo-oesophageal fistulae may provide symptomatic relief and improved quality of life. For further information, see Scenario: Symptomatic treatment.
    • Manage dyspnoea if present. See the CKS topic on Palliative cancer care - dyspnoea.
  • Provide holistic care of the person by considering management of other physical symptoms, and the psychological, social, and spiritual needs of the person and their family. For more information, see the CKS topic on Palliative care - general issues.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent: These recommendations are based on palliative care guidelines [International Association for Hospice and Palliative Care, 2004] and expert opinion from medical and palliative care literature [Ahmedzai, 2004; Estfan and LeGrand, 2004; Wee et al, 2012].

subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I manage a person with a cough due to infection?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Determine with the person, and their carers and family, what management is appropriate for the stage of illness.
    • In the terminal phase, antibiotics do not greatly alter the course of events, but their use is justified if it will make the person more comfortable (for example by reducing thick, infected sputum). If the decision has been made not to prescribe antibiotic treatment, this will need careful and sympathetic discussion with family or carers, who may perceive this as 'giving up' on their loved one, or leaving them to suffer. Management of symptoms, such as fever and respiratory secretions may be an alternative (see the CKS topic on Palliative cancer care - secretions).
    • If a pleural effusion is suspected, consider referral for drainage.
  • Options are to treat at home or admit for specialist care (such as hospital, specialist cancer centre, or hospice). Factors that may help support a decision on whether or not to admit include:
    • Whether or not the person can be managed at home.
    • The severity of the illness.
    • Comorbidities such as an immunocompromised state.
    • Whether the person is responding to treatment at home.
    • Whether the person requires treatment of an underlying cause (for example radiotherapy to a tumour, drainage of a pleural effusion).
  • If the decision is made to treat at home, consider treatment with an appropriate antibiotic.
  • Discuss with a specialist if there is uncertainty regarding appropriate treatment or place of management.
  • Also consider symptomatic treatment (to enhance the effectiveness of, or suppress, the cough). For more information, see Scenario: Symptomatic treatment.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent: These recommendations are based on pragmatic advice and expert opinion from medical and palliative care literature [Ahmedzai, 2004; Estfan and LeGrand, 2004; Chan, 2015; Regnard, 2010].

subChapters.fullItemName: Managing a cough of non-infective cause
subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I manage a person with a cough of known cause other than infection?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Determine with the person, and their carers and family, what management interventions are appropriate for the underlying cause of cough and the stage of illness, for example:
    • Treatment of the underlying cause of the cough if possible.
    • Referral for treatment of the underlying malignancy if needed (such as radiotherapy to a tumour, drainage of a pleural effusion).
    • Referral if the cause of the cough is not directly related to the underlying malignancy, but is more appropriately managed in secondary care (for example worsening chronic obstructive pulmonary disease).
    • Admission to hospital (for example acute exacerbation of heart failure).
  • To manage:
    • Malignancy-related causes of cough (such as a tumour or tracheo-oesophageal fistula) — involve a specialist in view of the need to tailor treatment to the person's underlying malignancy and co-existing problems, and the large variety of treatments available. These include radiotherapy, stenting of tracheo-oesophageal fistulae, aspiration of a pleural effusion, or corticosteroids.
    • Drug-related cough (such as angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors) — review the person's medication, as it may be appropriate to stop certain drugs or switch to an alternative.
    • Other, common causes of cough — these will usually be managed in primary care, but in some cases admission to hospital, or secondary care advice may be necessary. For more information, see the CKS topics on:
      • Asthma
      • Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease
      • Dyspepsia - proven GORD
      • Heart failure - chronic
  • If treatment of the underlying cause is not possible, or does not relieve the cough, consider symptomatic treatment (to enhance the effectiveness of, or suppress, the cough). For more information, see Scenario: Symptomatic treatment.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent: These recommendations are based on palliative care guideline [NHS Scotland, 2015] and expert opinion from palliative care literature [Ahmedzai, 2004; Estfan and LeGrand, 2004; Chan, 2015].
